title: Lehigh Valley Scene: Allentown Symphony conductor Diane Wittry honored for 20 years
text:
For 20 years, Diane Wittry says she has been driven by a desire to deliver "purple cows" to audiences at Miller Symphony Hall. Wittry's friends and colleagues recently spent an evening presenting the music director and conductor of the Allentown Symphony Orchestra with a few purple cows of her own during the 20th anniversary Tribute and Benefit Dinner in her honor on Oct. 1.
The event began with a 5:30 p.m. reception and an auction of 17 violins painted by local artists. The celebration continued with a tribute on the stage of Miller Symphony Hall, followed by dinner in the Rodale Community Room, catered by Karen Hunter.
About 175 were in attendance at the tribute, including past board presidents, patrons, supporters and dignitaries. About 125 remained for the dinner.
The night began in a way that was music to everyone's ears with the Painted Violin Auction raising nearly $10,000. Seventeen local artists donated their time and talents to transform retired, unplayable violins into works of art. The violins were displayed in the windows of Symphony Hall during September.
Parkland High School art teacher and artist Linda La Due presented Wittry with a specially painted violin as a keepsake from the event.
At the tribute, former symphony board member Michael Drabenstott served as the emcee and spoke about how Wittry has overseen a tremendous leap in the excellence of the orchestra during her tenure. She has kept her concerts fresh through innovative programming, showcasing the work of new composers as well as that of the great masters, he said.
"Diane is always looking for that unexpected twist for a concert to catch your attention," Drabenstott said. "Like trumpets sounding from the balcony or flamenco dancers sashaying across the stage. She calls these 'purple cows.'
"Diane's determination to achieve the best, whether it is a purple cow, or guest artist, or a new timpani, is why we have experienced 20 years of great concerts here at Miller Symphony Hall."
Drabenstott also mentioned how Wittry has inspired young conductors through her teaching and books, one of which, "Beyond the Baton," published by Oxford University Press, was nominated for a Pulitzer Prize in 2007.
Other highlights of the event included a video by Stephanie Gardner honoring Wittry and the Allentown Symphony Orchestra.
This was followed by a presentation to musicians celebrating 20 years or more with the orchestra. Each was presented with a certificate of congratulations from state Sen. Pat Browne and a gold pin designating their years of service from the Allentown Symphony Association.
Among the musicians honored for their longevity were Linda Kistler, with 60 years of service, and Lee Walck and Milt Focht , each with 50 years.
Government officials also showed their support for Wittry and gratitude for everything she has contributed through the years. Allentown Mayor Ed Pawlowski designated Oct. 1, 2015 as "Diane Wittry Day" in Allentown and presented her with a proclamation. Other proclamations were presented by State Reps. Pete Schweyer and Mike Schlossberg .
Wittry also received a framed print detailing her accomplishments with the Allentown Symphony Orchestra as well as a congratulatory letter from the President of the America League of Orchestras, Jesse Rosen.
Event sponsors included Donald and Maureen Frederick, William and Margaret Hecht, Alvin H. Butz, Joan Moran and William Fenza. Patrons included Peter and Carol Kern, and Missy and Sam Saxton .
Among the guests were Heather Rodale and Carl Barndt, Dr. Michael Badellino and Karen Badellino, Ruth and Charles Marcon, Joan Lardner Paul, Peter and Nancy Yenawine and David and Judy Mickenberg.
Jennifer Marangos is a freelance writer. Please send items for Scene to jennifer@zephyrosinc.com .

BAUM SCHOOL FALL GALA: The Baum School of Art's Fall Gala, this year honoring the Dent family for three generations of support, is Oct. 17 at the Baum School of Art in Allentown. Special guest visiting-artist Gary T. Erbe will attend. The black tie-optional event will begin with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at 5:30 p.m., followed by dinner at 8 p.m. Catering will be by Karen Hunter. The evening includes a silent auction. Tickets are $150. To purchase tickets, call 610-433-0032.
GLASS BLAST: The Glass Studio at the Banana Factory will hold its second annual Glass Blast event 7-10 p.m. Oct. 23 in the Fowler Blast Furnace Room at the ArtsQuest Center at SteelStacks, Bethlehem. The party, a fundraiser for the ArtsQuest Glass Studio, will include glass blowing, live music and food. All guests receive a handmade drinking glass to take home as a souvenir. Tickets are $65; $60, ArtsQuest Center members. New this year is a VIP ticket option — $95; $90, members — that allows access to the event one hour early. For tickets see: tix.artsquest.org/tickets.
LEGACY SUMMIT: The first annual CREW (Commercial Real Estate Women Network) Lehigh Valley Legacy Summit, "We Dare You: The Rewards of Risk Taking," will be 8 a.m. to 1:15 p.m. Oct. 27 at the Renaissance Allentown Hotel. The cost is $100; $75, members; $60, students. Register at www.crewlehighvalley.org by Oct. 22.
COCKTAILS & COLLECTING: The Allentown Art Museum presents its 10th annual Cocktails & Collecting fundraiser, which blends art, hors d'oeuvres, collecting and socializing, 6-9 p.m. Nov. 7. Artists from the Lehigh Valley and beyond will showcase, talk about and sell their works. Tickets: $125; $100, members, in advance; $150 and $125 at the door. For tickets, call the museum at 610-432-4333, ext. 110.
POWER OF THE PURSE: The United Way Women's Leadership Council invites community members to do holiday shopping early and for a cause during its annual Power of the Purse event. Power of the Purse will be held 5:30-8 p.m. Nov. 12 in Canova Commons at Cedar Crest College, 100 College Drive, Allentown. Wine and hors d'oeuvres will be served and Lehigh Valley vendors will sell their goods. Tickets are $45, advance; $50, door. A $75 sponsorship fee includes ticket and sponsor benefits. A portion of all sales will benefit Women's Leadership Council and its signature projects benefiting women and children. For more information or to register contact Marcy McKinney at 610-807-5708.
BOUNTIFUL BOWL: Meals on Wheels presents its 15th annual Bountiful Bowl fundraiser 7-10 p.m. Nov. 13 at DeSales University, 2755 Station Ave., Center Valley. The event includes grazing stations, an open bar, music and a silent auction of handcrafted bowls and other items. There will be a presentation of the first Bob Wood Legacy Award to longtime event co-chairwoman Mary Anne Johnson. Tickets: $100. Info: including sponsorship opportunities: 610-388-2563.
